Given the randomness of evolution it's tricky to really come up with a final theory for something so useless.

Maybe it's side effect of speech - since this is also unique to us. Why though. Maybe increased weight allowed us finer control of jaw movements allowing us to learn complex speech earlier in our lives. A lot of kids struggle with accurate movement with their limbs but learn speaking accurate sounds pretty early on.

Or it could really have been an early random mutation we had when we weren't too many, and mating with bigger chins was a thing at the time.

Or there was a period of some intense dust/pollen that kept our noses clogged up, we were breathing mostly through our mouths and additional weight helped keep mouth open.

Or maybe cold shivers are more visible when there is chin and with our increasingly dynamic society it helped us identify those who needed help quicker.

Or as societies grew and you needed to lead increasingly larger groups of people, from afar it was easier to see if person is talking if they had a larger chin. This then would contribute to sexual preferences.

Or beards became a major status symbol and a random mutation of chin allowed a look of a larger, more pronounced beard.

comment_text: I think it comes down to the need for anchor points for a more dextrous tongue that enabled speech. If you look at the mandibles of other hominids, the space inside is concave, sloping inward and downward like a spoon. Ours has straight sides. That probably gives our tongues better anchor points and a greater range of movement. And before you say "this was debunked already," the hypotheses Hank is talking about was that the chin directly aids speech. But in this case, the chin is just a side-effect of the steep sides of our mandibles which were advantageous in the development of speech.

The chin helps to express emotions such as disgust and contempt. It can function as a warning mechanism.
Although its difficult to think of a selection pressure that would necessarily cause such an adaptation.... unless our ancestors thought that what we consider, "negative" emotions were attractive... leading to a sexual selective pressure.
Maybe the presence of contempt and disgust made our ancestral males more likely to be effective at protecting the family unit from other more dangerous individuals. Leading to higher survival rates of their offspring...
Whereas more peaceful individuals would be less effective at doing this.
This could create an increase in both sexual attraction towards members of the population that exhibit a greater ability to express negative emotions in the face... and also a greater chance of their offspring living to the age of sexual maturity in order to reproduce
Even if this only accounted for a 1-2% increase is offspring survival it would eventually catalyze into a statistically relevant change in the frequency of alleles among the population.
But there are definitely much stranger traits to be found in the animal kingdom than the human chin.

Self-domestication leading to domestication syndrome? One typical effect of mammalian domestication syndrome is craniofacial morphological changes not seen in their wild forebears.
Presumably, like cats, as we stepped away from many of the natural selectors of nature as our society grew in complexity, we essentially entered into a self-regulated breeding and domestication program of sorts.
For example, now that we generally don't have to worry about predation, hunting, gathering, navigating, or even seeing things past 50 feet coupled with the amazing invention of glasses, we have effectively removed our selectors against poor vision. Ergo, since it is no longer a major detriment, roughly half of the people you come across need or would benefit from corrective eyewear.
To further expand, as our society grew, we presumably generally needed more agreeable and team-oriented people to maintain our complex society. In doing so, like selecting for tameness and temperament in dogs, we basically domesticated ourselves.

Just a hypothesis, but I think it makes sense and is surprisingly plausible.

Somewhat interesting thing about why theyre called spandrels and how it ties to adaptation. Spandrels are an architectural term for that space you have in between arches. Cause when you put two arches together you have to have this triangular space in between. So like the chin, the spandrels weren't actually developed by themselves, but as a byproduct of another decision in a different part of the structure.
This applies to the rest of natural adaption because we often assume everything has a purpose, when really that adaption could have come entirely as a byproduct of something else.
So we might assume a fish is pink or it helps it find a mate or some other function, but really the fish could be pink because the only food it can eat happens to turn it pink.

Hi, biological population and evolution analyst here, my best educated guess is that we have chins for the same reason animals have a crest on the top of the skull. In fact we basically agree amongst the community that bone growth is mostly attributed to muscle attachment, as more surface area=more attachment surface=more muscular potential. So yes my best assumption is the chin exists as a method of muscular attachment for the complex movements our mouths make to perform the tasks that we require of it. (Such as talking, smiling, frowning, chewing, etc.)
Edit: If you want evidence of this, look in a mirror and just, move your mouth around. Pay attention to how much movement occurs in the chin area and think about how those muscles are moving

So, evolutionarily, human ancestors lost the sagittal crest along the top of their heads and right at about the same time the jaw structure changed - no longer could we bite with the incredible force of our ape cousins without the sagittal crest to anchor those large jaw muscles to.

This also seemed to coincide with an enlargement of the brain case inside the skull which allowed for more space for the frontal lobe to grow.

It also also seems to have coincided with a change in diet - many of the pre-human ancestors at the time are believed to have lived near the coast of Africa, an area ripe with shellfish which contain large amounts of Omega-3 fatty acids, a family of compounds which are incredibly great for our brain development.

I feel like the chin portion is probably an atavism or spandrel that simply developed alongside these changes or maybe thereafter. Could be used for sexual selection as many such traits tend to be.

The term "spandrel" comes from a classic evolutionary biology paper where the authors used the Spandrels of San Marco to argue against the use of "adaptionist stories", nice-sounding hypotheses about the adaptation of certain traits that have no actual evidence supporting it. The Spandrels of San Marco are beautifully adorned with art. The authors argue that you may be tempted to think the spandrels were made explicitly to display this art. In reality, they are the result of placing arches next to each other. They were just an open canvas for artists to use after the fact. Similarly, not all traits are the result of adaptation.

I have a couple of hypotheses.
1. The human at the time of getting more and more conscious of its existence started to philosophize more and more and to do this we adopted the position of resting our heads on our hands because that's what we'd commonly do when our thinking process gets deep.
2. The second one has to do with mouthbreathers. Humans before the homo sapiens tended to be nomads so they had to move constantly and actively hunt their food so the energy demand was much higher hence they had to breathe with more frequency and quantity to meet the physiological needs to survive on a daily basis. That said, when mankind became sedentary there was no longer needed to be breathing heavily to hunt and move around because as a species we learned to take advantage of what nature offered us and the need to run long distances to hunt down food eventually disappeared and our pharynx evolutionarily had to grow more to improve intake airflow in a resting state. This led to eventually getting us the characteristic of a loss of a really refined smell for a refinement of taste, both equilibrated in comparison to other animals who don't mind eating raw meat because the two senses are not that connected as in humans. And finally the use of the tongue to form such a great variety of sounds to communicate to each other, this had to make an important role to forming a cavity where the tongue could rest but at the same time a good range of movement and consistency to make cries, whispers, whistles...

I have found that people with very short chins tend to look "less intelligent" at least in the traditional academic sense to me at a glance. This could be for several reasons, but I think it is because chins tend to get longer and more defined as we grow into adults so somebody with a very small chin may appear to have not reached the typical developmental milestones physically which suggests a physical developmental disorder which may also have an intellectual developmental aspect. Fetal Alcohol syndrome for example will cause those who have it to have a short chin that did not properly develop as well as a mental developmental delay... To be clear I am not saying said people are stupid  I think stupid  is a very judgemental and subjective term that should be avoided when referring to a human being as a whole regardless of if they have a disability. Here's the answer to how we got our chin:

Some mammals take to wading in water. They spend a significant amount if time neck deep in water, keeping their face above water.

Why the chin?
At first they had no chin. Some young ones accidentally inhale water. This could potentially lead to pneumonia and death without procreating.
Thus there's an evolutionary pressure favoring ones who don't accidentally inhale water, or who do so less frequently.
If the bone below the mouth has even a slight protrusion putting it closer to the water, when the individual keeps their face above water their mouth is further from the water, decreasing the likelihood of accidentally inhaling water.

The larger the protrusion, the higher their likelihood of surviving and mating. Over millions of years, this created the jaw.

This happened during our evolution from Australopithecus to Hominidae. Some wading Australopithecus developed the downward protrusion of the jaw and upright posture. They spent much time wading in the water because they liked seafood. They also hunted and foraged on land.

A defect in the genes for jaw muscles later appeared in that group resulting in significantly smaller jaw muscles. The ones with the defect spent significantly more time in the water since the food on land was more difficult to chew.
Through millions of years of evolution, this led to a more pronounced chin along with the loss of body hair, webbing between fingers, fingertip wrinkling response to water, breath control, eventually to the hominids.

Being in water, these hominids didn't fear fire as land animals did. They eventually learned to cook food with it. This led to their gradual return to land as the cooking made food on land easier to chew.

As far as I'm aware, there is no data to support my statement. Why do humans have chins, with biological males tending to have broader chins? What other facial feature shares this same pattern? Beards. Why do humans have coarse hair in localized regions? Typically, to help dry sweat, to potentially distribute informative social odors, sexual signaling, and as an anti-friction surface(prevents chaffing). Being that chins are not typically sweaty like an arm pit and are typically kept clean, anti-friction and sexual selection seem likely. Why would male faces need protection from friction? Well, perhaps like lions, it's to prevent inter-species aggression from causing too much damage. Being bipedal, our hands are freed up and we have the structural ability to punch and use weapons. The face is quite vulnerable to these types of attacks. Thick, coarse hair both cushions, prevents friction, and deflects blows. Having a stronger jaw would be helpful for this. Why only us? Well, why don't Chinese Water Deer have antlers? They don't need them. Humans have the weakest jaws compared to other apes and hominids. Thus chins.

(Why do I have a feeling that the only people looking into this are men?) The really obvious answer is that it has to do with breastfeeding. Because of the malformation of the human skull due to the increase in the size of the cranium and the decrease in the size of the muzzle, babies have a lower chance of being able to latch unless their facial structure changes to match the shape of the breast. A baby with no Chin is less likely to find a good latch. The chin changes the angle of approach where a chinless baby would be rooting around for something that is on top of a mound and hard to match with a chinless facial structure.

Regardless of why we developed breasts, as opposed to simple mammary tissue like every other mammal, chins would of been a simultaneous evolution to continue allowing a baby to aim correctly for a proper latch. (Go watch a video of rooting reflex and tell me if that chin isn't being used as a sensory device to aim correctly)

Some cultures less obviously point with a small gesture by gazing in a direction and lift their chins, some lift their chin and pursing their lips, as if their chin or pursed lips were a pointing finger. More than just gazing in a direction, the chin lift is a nonverbal cue, a way of saying there's something over there I want you to see. The small and quite gesture could be beneficial on a hunt but I cant say if having the chin that we have helps with that or not.

Interestingly and maybe related, dogs differ from wolfs in part because of their ability to sense desired meaning in human facial pointing which would have been very useful on a hunt.

I hope someone cares to test this, a chin helps one better see a direction communicated, hypothesis.
